April 8, 1990: Fiction
THE BOURNE ULTIMATUM, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $21.) Jason
Bourne plans to infiltrate the ruthless Medusa  Bridage as part of a plot to trap his
archenemy, Carlos the Jackal.
OH, THE PLACES YOU'LL GO! by Dr. Seuss. (Random House,  $12.95.) The
problems of finding your way through life; in  verse and pictures.
CLEAR AND PRESENT DANGER, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $21.95.)  The
C.I.A.'s Jack Ryan fights Colombian drug lords.
DEVICES AND DESIRES, by P. D. James. (Knopf, $19.95.) Adam  Dalgliesh
puzzles over a series of killings on the windy  Norfolk coast.
THE SCIONS OF SHANNARA, by Terry Brooks. (Del Rey/Ballantine,  $19.95.)
The adventures of two brothers who practice magic in  a fantasy land.
THE BAD PLACE, by Dean R. Koontz. (Putnam, $19.95.) A  troubled sleepwalker
hires a detective team to investigate  his behavior.
BITTER SWEET, by LaVyrle Spencer. (Putnam, $18.95.) A  widow's ordeal after
meeting her high school flame, now a  less than happily married man.
CARIBBEAN, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $22.95.) The  history of
the sea islands.
VINELAND, by Thomas Pynchon. (Little, Brown, $19.95.) The  passions of the
60's continue to govern the lives of members  of a community in California.
DADDY, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $19.95.) Unexpected  crisis wreck the safe,
predictable world a man has built for  himself and his family.
MASQUERADE, by Janet Dailey. (Little, Brown, $19.95.) An  encounter with a
masked man during a carnival in Nice brings  a New Orleans heiress romance and
series of puzzles.
LONDON FIELDS, by Martin Amis. (Harmony, $19.95.)  Destruction and self-
destruction permeate a grim London in  1999, a time when global catastrophe
impends.
TALES FROM MARGARITAVILLE, by Jimmy Buffett. (Harcourt Brace
Jovanovich, $16.95.) Short stories set on a mythical  Caribbean island.
BURN MARKS, by Sara Paretsky. (Delacorte, $17.95.) The  disappearance of her
dearest aunt takes the private eye V.I.  Warshawski into the dark side of Chicago's
political world.
COLD HARBOUR, by Jack Higgins. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.)  The O.S.S.
April 8, 1990
Non-Fiction
MEANS OF ASCENT, by Robert A. Caro. (Knopf, $24.95.) Lyndon  Johnson's
seven-year pursuit of a seat in the Senate, won in  1948 by 87 votes.
MEGATRENDS 2000, by John Naisbitt and Patricia Aburdene.  (Morrow, $21.95.)
Prognostications for the next decade.
BARBARIANS AT THE GATE, by Bryan Burrough and John Helyar.  (Harper &
Row, $22.95.) The 1988 battle for control of RJR  Nabisco.
LIAR'S POKER by Michael Lewis. (Norton, $19.95.) Wall  Street's tumultuous
WHAT I SAW AT THE REVOLUTION, by Peggy Noonan. (Random  House,
$19.95.) The memoirs of a former Presidential  speechwriter.
IT WAS ON FIRE WHEN I LAY DOWN ON IT, by Robert Fulghum.  (Villard,
$17.95.) A new collection of inspirational essays.
PARTING WITH ILLUSIONS, by Vladimir Pozner. (Atlantic  Monthly, $19.95.) The
autobiography of a man, raised in New  York, who became a commentator on
Radio Moscow.
THE SPY WENT DANCING, by Aline, Countess of Romanones.  (Putnam,
$19.95.) A World War II O.S.S. operative resumes her  work during the 60's.
ALL I REALLY NEED TO KNOW I LEARNED IN KINDERGARTEN, by  Robert
Fulghum. (Villard, $17.95.) Inspirational essays.
A BRIEF HISTORY OF TIME, by Stephen W. Hawking. (Bantam,  $18.95.) A
scientist reviews efforts to create a unified  theory of the universe.
DEEP COVER, by Michael Levine. (Delacorte, $19.95.) The  political account of
the Drug Enforcement Administration by a  former agent.
THE CUCKOO'S EGG, by Clifford Stoll. (Doubleday, $19.95.) An  astrophysicist
tells how he stalked a computer hacker.
THE EMPEROR'S NEW MIND, by Roger Penrose. (Oxford  University, $24.95.)
Why computers will never replace human  thinking.
RAW RECRUITS, by Alexander Wolff and Armen Keteylan.  (Pocket, $18.95.)
How current recruitment practices corrupt  college basketball players, coaches
and their schools.
HEAD FIRST, by Norman Cousins. (Dutton, $19.95.) How the  brain affects the
body's endocrine and immune systems.
